name: Amber
description: Amber is simply fossilized tree sap, formed and hardened over many thousands of years. Prized for its beauty, amber is often used in accessories such as necklaces and earrings. Amber containing a trapped insect, such as a bee or ant, can fetch a particularly high price.

name: Ammonite
description: Ammonites were sea creatures with shells ranging from a few inches to a few feet in diameter. However, theories speculate that giant varieties existed as well, with shells six feet in diameter. Oddly, the ammonite is a closer relative to the squid or octopus than to the chambered nautilus.

name: Ankylosaurus
description: The ankylosaurus is famous for the distinctive armor that covered its body from head to toe. This armor consisted of large bone knobs and plates covered in a thick, leathery skin. When threatened by the carnivorous dinosaurs, it would swing its club-like tail to protect itself.

sections.name: Ankylo Skull
sections.shortName_JP: アンキロサウルスのあたま

sections.name: Ankylo Torso
sections.shortName_JP: アンキロサウルスのからだ

sections.name: Ankylo Tail
sections.shortName_JP: アンキロサウルスのしっぽ

name: Anomalocaris
description: Anomalocaris lived in the water long before the dinosaurs and are known for their "distinctive" look. They looked so peculiar that people originally thought they were multiple fossils stacked on top of each other! As a delightful side note, "anomalocaris" means "abnormal shrimp." Obviously this animal has a certain reputation in the scientific community!

name: Archaeopteryx
description: The archaeopteryx is considered a close relative to the ancestors of modern birds. Despite the similarities, its teeth and three-clawed hands contained marked differences. As its bones were hollow to keep its body lighter and allow for flight, fossils rarely survive.

name: Archelon
description: With a name that literally means "ruler turtle," the archelon was an ancient species of sea turtle. Reaching 13 feet in length and two metric tons in weight, it was a giant that lived up to its name. It likely ate jellyfish and squid, though theories say it may have also preyed on ammonites. Unlike with modern turtles, its shell was too soft to allow it to pull in its limbs for a defensive position.

sections.name: Archelon Skull
sections.shortName_JP: アーケロンのあたま

sections.name: Archelon Tail
sections.shortName_JP: アーケロンのからだ

name: Australopith
description: The australopith, thought to be one of the links between humans and apes, emerged 4,000,000 years ago. They lived long ago, even before the ancestors of the modern humans, so there are profound differences.

name: Brachiosaurus
description: Brachiosaurus, whose name means 'arm lizard', was one of the largest herbivorous dinosaurs. Due to its long front legs and elongated neck, it seems to have specialized in eating plants up high. Alas, in order to support its large size, it likely needed to eat more or less every waking hour.

sections.name: Brachio Skull
sections.shortName_JP: ブラキオサウルスのあたま

sections.name: Brachio Chest
sections.shortName_JP: ブラキオサウルスのむね

sections.name: Brachio Pelvis
sections.shortName_JP: ブラキオサウルスのこし

sections.name: Brachio Tail
sections.shortName_JP: ブラキオサウルスのしっぽ

name: Coprolite
description: Fossilized dung might not sound too exciting, but coprolites are a treasure trove of information. If they contain seeds, bones, or scales, you can gain insight into the animal's natural diet. Dung doesn't easily turn into fossils, so they're considered quite precious and hard to come by.

name: Deinonychus
description: You may not have heard of Deinonychus, but you may have heard of its cousin, the Velociraptor. Both were predators distinguished by their frighteningly huge toe claws. They also likely had feathers. The main difference about them? Size. Deinonychus was about 7 feet tall and weighed 160 pounds. Little Velociraptor, on the other wing, was a compact two feet tall and weighed only about 33 pounds.

sections.name: Deinony Torso
sections.shortName_JP: ディノニクスのあたま

sections.name: Deinony Tail
sections.shortName_JP: ディノニクスのしっぽ

name: Dimetrodon
description: Despite its reptilian appearance, the dimetrodon was not actually a dinosaur, as you'd assume. It was, in fact, a mammal-like reptile that went extinct before the first dinosaurs appeared. It had knife-like teeth for slicing as well as smaller ones for crushing. The large fan on its back was used to regulate body temperature-- an important feature of the time.

sections.name: Dimetrodon Skull
sections.shortName_JP: ディメトロドンのあたま

sections.name: Dimetrodon Torso
sections.shortName_JP: ディメトロドンのからだ

name: Dinosaur Track
description: Unlike other fossils, fossilized foot-prints give us a glimpse of how the creature in question actually lived. Thanks to modern science, we can determine quite a lot about the particular gaits of some creatures. This includes how they supported their weight, their posture when walking, and even walking speed.

name: Diplodocus
description: The diplodocus was a herbivore of the late Jurassic period sporting a tremendously long tail and neck. The neck was so long that, from snout to tail, its length could reach a staggering 175 feet long. Evidence suggests it would use its long, slender tail like a whip to defend itself from attackers.

sections.name: Diplo Skull
sections.shortName_JP: ディプロドクスのあたま

sections.name: Diplo Neck
sections.shortName_JP: ディプロドクスのくび

sections.name: Diplo Chest
sections.shortName_JP: ディプロドクスのむね

sections.name: Diplo Pelvis
sections.shortName_JP: ディプロドクスのこし

sections.name: Diplo Tail
sections.shortName_JP: ディプロドクスのしっぽ

sections.name: Diplo Tail Tip
sections.shortName_JP: ディプロドクスのしっぽのさき

name: Dunkleosteus
description: The Dunkleosteus flourished long before the dinosaurs and was a sort of armored fish. Curiously, only fossils for the head and shoulders have been found. We must simply imagine the rest!

name: Eusthenopteron
description: The eusthenopteron is famous for being the link between fish and land animals long before dinosaurs. It seems to have had strong fins capable of pulling it around areas where the water was shallow. When most creatures lived in the sea...they dreamed of land. If not for them, we mightn't be here today!

name: Iguanodon
description: The iguanodon is so named because it was mistakenly believed to be a large iguana. An herbivore, it is famous for its spikelike thumb claws, which seem somewhat odd on a nonpredator. Supposedly it would run on two legs but would use all four when it was just walking at its leisure.

sections.name: Iguanodon Skull
sections.shortName_JP: イグアノドンのあたま

sections.name: Iguanodon Torso
sections.shortName_JP: イグアノドンのからだ

sections.name: Iguanodon Tail
sections.shortName_JP: イグアノドンのしっぽ

name: Juramaia
description: The juramaia: one of the first mammals, and one of the few to live alongside the dinosaurs! In order to hide from much larger dinosaurs, it was less than four inches long and quite unobtrusive. Some even theorize that these mammals were nocturnal until the dinosaurs went extinct. They needed every advantage to live among those behemoths.

name: Mammoth
description: The mammoth was a giant, woolly elephant-like animal equipped with long, deadly tusks. Aside from protection, the tusks were also likely used to clear paths through the snow. One theory states that mammoths became extinct at the end of the last ice age due to a lack of food.

sections.name: Mammoth Skull
sections.shortName_JP: マンモスのあたま

sections.name: Mammoth Torso
sections.shortName_JP: マンモスのからだ

name: Megacerops
description: The megacerops was a mammalian grazer with a Y-shaped horn on its nose. It is a distant relative of the rhinoceros, which the horn helps give away. Its main source of food was soft grass, but climate change caused this food source to disappear. Ultimately, without a thriving source of fresh food, megacerops joined other creatures in extinction.

sections.name: Megacero Skull
sections.shortName_JP: メガセロプスのあたま

sections.name: Megacero Torso
sections.shortName_JP: メガセロプスのからだ

sections.name: Megacero Tail
sections.shortName_JP: メガセロプスのしっぽ

name: Megaloceros
description: The Megaloceros was a relative of the deer that lived during the Ice Age, long after the dinosaurs. It was also known as "megaloceros giganteus," which just means "deer with large horns." True to their name, they were deer with antlers spanning roughly 10 feet across!

sections.name: Left Megalo Side
sections.shortName_JP: メガロケロスのひだりはんしん

sections.name: Right Megalo Side
sections.shortName_JP: メガロケロスのみぎはんしん

name: Myllokunmingia
description: Said to be one of the oldest fish-like animals, it lived well before the dinosaurs. It was about an inch long and seems to have had no lower jaw. It is awe-inspiring imagining such ancient life! There is much we still don’t know. We may yet discover even older organisms with even fewer jaws!

name: Ophthalmosaurus
description: Opthalmosaurus's name means "eye lizard," and its face was quite dominated by those great orbs! Beside their cutifying effect, these eyes gave the creature great vision, making it a very successful hunter.

sections.name: Ophthalmo Skull
sections.shortName_JP: オフタルモサウルスのあたま

sections.name: Ophthalmo Torso
sections.shortName_JP: オフタルモサウルスのからだ

name: Pachycephalosaurus
description: Pachycephalosaurus was, to be blunt, not the brightest star in the dinosaur firmament. What I mean is, with its incredibly thick skull—some 10 inches thick in spots—it didn't have much room for... well, for brains. Its brain was likely quite small, but at least it was extremely safe...in its...bony...prison.

sections.name: Pachy Skull
sections.shortName_JP: パキケファロのあたま

sections.name: Pachy Tail
sections.shortName_JP: パキケファロのからだ

name: Parasaurolophus
description: The parasaur is well known for the distinctive head crest extending from its nose to behind its head. The crest was formed from a hollow bone that was more than a yard in length. Theories hold that it was used to amplify the creature's vocalizations for a variety of reasons.

sections.name: Parasaur Skull
sections.shortName_JP: パラサウロロフスのあたま

sections.name: Parasaur Torso
sections.shortName_JP: パラサウロロフスのからだ

sections.name: Parasaur Tail
sections.shortName_JP: パラサウロロフスのしっぽ

name: Plesiosaurus
description: While not a dinosaur itself, the plesiosaur, a marine reptile, did live alongside the dinosaurs. These creatures could reach lengths of 7 m or longer, the bulk of that being their long necks. Plesiosaurs are commonly mistaken for certain kinds of mythical sea monsters, such as "Nessie."

sections.name: Plesio Skull
sections.shortName_JP: フタバサウルスのあたま

sections.name: Plesio Body
sections.shortName_JP: フタバサウルスのからだ

sections.name: Plesio Tail
sections.shortName_JP: フタバサウルスのしっぽ

name: Pteranodon
description: Pteranodons were a type of winged reptile, perhaps the ancestors of common birds. With their wings spread, they were about the size of a small airplane, but their bodies were very light. Strangely, they weighed less than 50 pounds, with wings made from skin, allowing for ease of flight.

sections.name: Ptera Body
sections.shortName_JP: プテラノドンのあたま

sections.name: Left Ptera Wing
sections.shortName_JP: プテラノドンのさよく

sections.name: Right Ptera Wing
sections.shortName_JP: プテラノドンのうよく

name: Quetzalcoatlus
description: The undisputed ruler of the skies...at least during the late Cretaceous period. It had a magnificent wingspan of roughly 36 feet, making it one of the largest flying animals ever! While it no doubt soared magnificently, we now know that it alsso crawled on all fours.

sections.name: Quetzal Torso
sections.shortName_JP: ケツァルコアトルスのあたま

sections.name: Left Quetzal Wing
sections.shortName_JP: ケツァルコアトルスのさよく

sections.name: Right Quetzal Wing
sections.shortName_JP: ケツァルコアトルスのうよく

name: Sabertooth Tiger
description: The sabertooth tiger was about the size of a lion and is famous for its two long canine teeth. It would prey mostly on woolly mammoths, but climate change made that difficult. Eventually, the changing climate and competition with humans for food drove these creatures to extinction.

sections.name: Sabertooth Skull
sections.shortName_JP: スミロドンのあたま

sections.name: Sabertooth Tail
sections.shortName_JP: スミロドンのからだ

name: Shark-Tooth Pattern
description: The fossilized shark tooth has a distinctive serrated edge, like a steak knife. Sharks have existed since before the dinosaurs, but their appearance seems to have hardly changed at all. Their age actually puts them at a time even before plants had fully propagated over every continent.

name: Spinosaurus
description: The spinosaurus is famous for the sail on its back, made up of skin stretched over spikelike bones. The assumption is that these sails were used to help regulate body temperature, common for reptiles. In addition to having this large sail, it is also the largest of the carnivorous dinosaurs. Despite being so commanding, its diet most likely consisted of fish from swampy, marshy regions.

sections.name: Spino Skull
sections.shortName_JP: スピノサウルスのあたま

sections.name: Spino Torso
sections.shortName_JP: スピノサウルスのからだ

sections.name: Spino Tail
sections.shortName_JP: スピノサウルスのしっぽ

name: Stegosaurus
description: You can't talk about Stegosaurus without talking about the distinctive diamond-shaped plates on its back. These plates, while made of bone, were not actually connected to the animal's skeleton! They simply grew out from the skin, remarkably enough, they were up to two feet tall and similarly wide. It's not clear exactly how the plates were arranged or what they were for. Yet more mysteries of the ancients!

sections.name: Stego Skull
sections.shortName_JP: ステゴサウルスのあたま

sections.name: Stego Torso
sections.shortName_JP: ステゴサウルスのからだ

sections.name: Stego Tail
sections.shortName_JP: ステゴサウルスのしっぽ

sections.name: T. Rex Skull
sections.shortName_JP: Tレックスのあたま

sections.name: T. Rex Torso
sections.shortName_JP: Tレックスのからだ

sections.name: T. Rex Tail
sections.shortName_JP: Tレックスのしっぽ

name: Triceratops
description: The triceratops was a very large herbivore, commonly identified by its three horns and large bone frill. Its horns were likely used for turf wars and fighting over females rather than for protection. While it's true that it most likely lived in the same era as the T.rex, the two probably didn't fight much.

sections.name: Tricera Skull
sections.shortName_JP: トリケラトプスのあたま

sections.name: Tricera Torso
sections.shortName_JP: トリケラトプスのからだ

sections.name: Tricera Tail
sections.shortName_JP: トリケラトプスのしっぽ

name: Trilobite
description: Similar in appearance to a wood louse, the trilobite was an ancient sea-dwelling arthropod. It could range between 4 mm and 70 cm in length, depending on various factors. The trilobite was one of the first creatures to have eyes and the ability to detect enemies and prey.
